defendants.name: RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE AND ANR

respondents.name: RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE AND ANR

key_issues: Here are the key legal issues:

• Prior user vs registered trademark owner: Whether the petitioner's prior use of "Clari" formative marks prior to the respondent's registration date affects the respondent's right to register the mark "CLARIWASH".

• Simultaneous use and concurrent user: Whether the respondents can claim concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act, given that their trademark application was filed after they started using the mark.

• Inconsistencies in Examination Report: Whether the Registry's issuance of a Certificate of Registration with incorrect information ("CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH") affects the validity of the respondent's registration.
• Deed of Assignment and Transfer Agreement: Whether the petitioner acquired all rights, including reputation and goodwill, to the "Clari" formative marks from Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals.
• Trademark infringement claims: Whether the respondent's use of "CLARIWASH" constitutes trademark infringement against the petitioner's existing trademarks.

• Burden of proof in cancellation proceedings: Who bears the burden of proof in these proceedings, and whether the petitioner has met its burden to show that the respondent's registration should be cancelled.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD. vs RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING AND ANOTHER**

**Background:**
The present case is a cancellation petition filed by L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd. (petitioner) seeking removal of the registered trademark "CLARIWASH" ( respondent no.1's mark) from the Register of Trademarks.

**Case Set-up by Petitioner:**

* The petitioner is the proprietor of various trademarks with the word "Clari".
* The "CLARIWASH" mark was adopted in 2010 by a predecessor company, Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals Pvt. Ltd., which was acquired by the petitioner in 2013.
* The petitioner has been using the "Clari" formative marks since 2009.
* Respondent no.1 applied for registration of "CLARIWASH" on April 16, 2010, but the first invoice submitted is dated May 10, 2010, which is after the registration of the "Clari" formative marks.

**Case Set-up by Respondent:**

* Respondent no.1 has filed a suit for infringement against the petitioner in the District Courts, Tis Hazari.
* Respondent no.1 claims that the Examination Report issued on January 3, 2012, was incorrect and notes the mark as "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH".
* Respondent no.1 argues that the Certificate of Registration was modified to reflect the correct mark.

**Legal Issues:**

* The main issue in this case is whether the respondent no.1's registration of "CLARIWASH" should be cancelled due to prior user rights of the petitioner.
* Another issue is whether the Examination Report issued by the Registrar of Trade Marks was incorrect and resulted in an improper modification of the Certificate of Registration.

**Arguments:**

* Petitioner argues that they have used the "Clari" formative marks since 2009, and respondent no.1's registration should be cancelled due to prior user rights.
* Respondent no.1 argues that their suit for infringement is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari, and that the Examination Report issued by the Registrar of Trade Marks was incorrect.

**Court Findings:**

* The court held that the respondent no.1's registration should not be cancelled due to prior user rights.
* However, the court also found that the modification of the Certificate of Registration from "CHARIWASH" to "CLARIWASH" without a fresh examination was an error and in contravention of Section 32(3) of the Trademarks Act.

**Decision:**

* The court refused to cancel respondent no.1's registration of "CLARIWASH", but ordered that the modification of the Certificate of Registration be rectified by issuing a Fresh Examination Report.

In conclusion, the court held in favor of the respondent no.1 and refused to grant cancellation of the trademark "CLARIWASH" due to prior user rights. However, it also found that the modification of the Certificate of Registration was an error and ordered that a fresh examination be conducted.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 1 of 10 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
Judgment Reserved on:  27th February, 2023  
Judgment Delivered on: 23rd March, 2023  
 
+  
 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
 
LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD.  
 
       
  ..... Petitioner 
Through: 
Mr. 
S.K. 
Bansal 
and 
Mr.Ajay 
Amitabh Suman, Advocates 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
RAJESH KUMAR TANEJA TRADING  
AS INNOVATIVE DERMA CARE AND ANR 
...... Respondents 
Through: 
Mr. Pramod Kumar Singh and 
Ms. Priya Nagpal, Advocates for R-1. 
 
Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, 
CGSC with Mr. Srish Kumar Mishra, 
Mr. 
Sagar 
Mehlawat 
and 
Mr.Alexander 
Mathai 
Paikaday, 
Advocates for R-2. 
 
CORAM: 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
JUDGMENT 
1. 
The present cancellation petition has been filed on behalf of the 
petitioner seeking removal of impugned trademark „CLARIWASH‟ 
registered under No.1950938 in Class 03 in the name of the respondent no.1 
from the Register of Trademarks. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 2 of 10 
 
CASE SET UP BY THE PETITIONER 
2. 
The case set up in the petition is as under: 
2.1. The petitioner is the registered proprietor of various trademarks with 
the word “Clari”, details of which are given in paragraph 4 of the 
petition. The petitioner is engaged in the business of manufacture and 
sale of a wide range of hair care, skin care, toiletries and beauty 
products.  
2.2. The “CLARIWASH” mark was adopted in 2010 by the petitioner and 
has been used along with the other “Clari” formative marks. 
2.3. The first of the “Clari” formative marks were adopted by a company 
by the name of Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals Pvt. Ltd. [hereinafter 
“Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals”] in 2009. The petitioner acquired Cheryl‟s 
Cosmeceuticals in 2013 by way of a Deed of Assignment and Asset 
Transfer Agreement.  
2.4. By virtue of the said Deed of Assignment and Transfer Agreement, 
the reputation and goodwill related to various “Clari” formative marks 
stood transferred to the petitioner. 
2.5. The petitioner is the prior user of the “Clari” formative marks from 
the year 2009 on account of the user of his predecessor. 
2.6. The respondent no.1 applied for registration of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH” in Class 03 on 16th April, 2010 showing user from 
16th November, 2009. However, the first invoice filed on behalf of the 
respondent no.1 is dated 10th May, 2010, which is after the 
registration of the “Clari” formative marks. On the other hand, the 
registration granted in favour of the petitioner in respect of trademark 
“CLARI-FI” is of 3rd February, 2010 with user from 1st April, 2009. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 3 of 10 
 
2.7. It is further submitted that the respondent no.1 cannot claim the 
benefit of concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act as 
there was no use by the respondent no.1 at the time of the trademark 
application. The trademark application was filed on 16th April, 2010 
and the earliest invoice filed on behalf of the respondents is of 10th 
May, 2010. 
2.8. The Examination Report dated 3rd January, 2012 issued by the 
Registrar of Trade Marks wrongly notes the mark of the respondent 
no.1 as “CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Based on the 
aforesaid Examination Report, the Certificate of Registration of Trade 
Mark was issued in favour of the respondent no.1 for the word mark 
“CHARIWASH”. However, subsequently, the Certificate was 
modified by the Registry to “CLARIWASH”. 
2.9. The procedure adopted by the Registry in changing the Registration 
Certificate of word mark from “CHARIWASH” to “CLARIWASH” 
was an erroneous. Having discovered the error, the Registry should 
have 
proceeded 
for 
a 
fresh 
examination 
for 
the 
mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance in this regard is placed on the orders of the 
Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) in Vans Inc. USA v. 
Fateh Chand Bhansali and Anr., 2020 SCC OnLine IPAB 44 and 
Prajapati Constructions Ltd. v.  Manoj Ramanand Prajapati and 
Anr., 2018 SCC OnLine IPAB 313. 
CASE SET UP BY THE RESPONDENT 
3. 
The case set up by the respondent no.1 is as under: 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 4 of 10 
 
3.1. The respondent no.1 has filed a suit for infringement of the registered 
trademark “CLARIWASH” of the respondent no.1 against the 
petitioner, which is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari. 
3.2. Even though the Examination Report was in respect of the mark 
“CHARIWASH”, the Trademark Journal correctly published the 
mark “CLARIWASH” and not “CHARIWASH”. In May, 2012, the 
Trademark Registry erroneously issued Trademark Registration 
Certificate for the word mark “CHARIWASH”. The respondent no.1 
immediately filed an application to rectify the said clerical error and 
accordingly, the Trademark Registry rectified the error and issued a 
fresh Trademark Registration Certificate for the correct word mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance is placed on the judgment of a Coordinate 
Bench in Epsilon Publishing House Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India and 
Ors., 2009 SCC OnLine Del 3922.  
3.3. Though the petitioner claims adoption of the mark “CLARIWASH” 
in the year 2010, nothing has been filed in support of the same. 
Further, the petitioner has not filed any application for registration of 
the mark “CLARIWASH” till date. 
3.4. Use of the mark “CLARIWASH” by the petitioner or its predecessor 
was only in the year 2013. Attention of the Court in this regard is 
drawn to the invoices filed on behalf petitioner. 
3.5. The petitioner uses several other marks other than the “Clari” 
formative marks. Therefore, it cannot be said that “Clari” belongs to a 
family of marks. 
3.6. The petitioner cannot claim any monopoly on a part of the trademark 
“Clari”. The fact that the petitioner has various marks registered with 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 5 of 10 
 
the prefix “Clari” does not mean that the registration granted in favour 
of the respondent no.1 for the mark “CLARIWASH” is defective. 
There are a number of trademarks registered where the word “Clari” 
has been used as a prefix or suffix.  
3.7. The petitioner was aware of the respondent‟s use of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH”, yet never applied for its trademark registration. 
4. 
Despite opportunity being granted, the respondent no.2 has not filed 
any reply/counter statement or written submissions in the present petition. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
5. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
6. 
In the present case, it appears from the record that the Trademarks 
Registry erroneously issued the Examination Report for the mark 
“CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Yet again, the Registry issued 
a Trademark Registration Certificate in favour of the respondent, wherein 
the mark of the respondent was wrongly shown as “CHARIWASH”. 
Immediately thereafter, an application was filed on behalf of the respondents 
on 14th June, 2012, requesting for rectification of the clerical error and the 
same was allowed by the Registry and a correct Trademark Registration 
Certificate was issued in favour of the respondent for the mark 
“CLARIWASH”. However, it is pertinent to note that the mark of the 
respondent no.1 was published correctly as “CLARIWASH” in the 
Trademark Journal No.1519 on 16th January, 2012.  Therefore, it was open 
for the petitioner or its predecessor to oppose the said application, which 
they failed to do. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 6 of 10 
 
7. 
If the Registrar has committed an error and issued a faulty 
examination report, the respondent no.1 cannot be faulted for the same.  It is 
not that the respondent no.1 had misrepresented or misled the trademark 
Registry into issuing a faulty examination report.  The registration of a 
trademark entails valuable rights and the respondent no.1 cannot be deprived 
of the same on account of mistake committed by the Registry. Therefore, 
this by itself cannot be the ground for removal of the registration granted in 
favour of the respondent no.1. 
8. 
In Epsilon Publishing (supra), a Coordinate Bench of this Court was 
seized of a petition challenging the order of the Registrar renewing the 
trademark granted in favour of the respondent therein.  The ground taken by 
the petitioner was that since the respondent had not filed an application for 
renewal of the registration before its expiration and not paid the surcharge, 
the Registrar was required to remove the trademark from the Register.  
While noting that the Trade Marks Registry has not adhered to the statutory 
timelines, it was held that the respondent cannot be penalized for the same 
and would be entitled to pursue its renewal application.  In the said case, the 
Registrar had admitted that the renewal application filed on behalf of the 
private respondent was not examined and therefore, could not be processed 
further.  It was observed that the private respondent could not be deprived of 
its rights on account of the fault of the Registrar. The relevant observations 
of the court as set out in paragraph 26 are reproduced below: 
“26. 
There may be merit in the contention that the Registrar 
has to follow the procedure as prescribed; however, the essential 
question is not whether the Registrar has any discretion in the 
matter, but, what are the consequences of the Registrar not 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 7 of 10 
 
following the established procedure? Plainly, in the facts of the 
present case, it is apparent that the Trademark Registry has not 
adhered to the timelines as required. Surely, respondent no.3 
cannot be penalised for the same and would be entitled to purse its 
application for renewal of its trademark. The same was filed well 
within the period of six months and even though the same was not 
accompanied by a fee of surcharge, nonetheless, respondent no.3 
had the right to know the fate of its application. Since no 
deficiency was pointed out at the material time, respondent no.3 
cannot be deprived of its valuable rights to cure the defects within 
the prescribed period. The Registrar also did not advertise the 
removal of the trademark as required under section 25(4) of the 
Act read with Rule 66 of the 2002 Rules. Such advertisement 
would have provided another opportunity for the petitioner to seek 
restoration of the trademark.” 
9. 
The dicta of the aforesaid judgment is squarely applicable to the 
present case. The respondent no.1 cannot be deprived of his valuable rights 
of registration on account of the error of the Registry. 
10. 
Counsel for the petitioner has relied upon the orders passed by the 
IPAB in Prajapati Constructions (supra) and Vans Inc. USA (supra) in 
support of his submission that the Registrar of Trade Marks has to follow 
the statutory procedure prescribed under the Trade Marks Act, 1999 in 
respect of examination of a trade mark application. At the outset, it may be 
noted that both are interim orders passed by the IPAB and therefore, no 
reliance can be placed on the same in the present case, which is at the stage 
of final hearing. After noticing the various procedural lapses committed by 
the Trademark Registry, the IPAB only ordered that the respondent therein 
shall not rely upon the impugned registration in any proceedings during the 
pendency of the rectification proceedings.  There was no order for removal 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 8 of 10 
 
of the registration granted in favour of the respondent on account of lapses 
committed by the Registry.  
11. 
Reliance has also been placed on the order passed by the IPAB in 
Jahangir Biri Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Mohd. Dildar Hossain (Proporietor) & 
Anr., 2018 (76) PTC 479 [IPAB]. In the aforesaid order, the marks of the 
petitioner and the respondent were identical, namely, “HOWRAH BIDI”. 
The respondent therein had merely added a number to the mark “HOWRAH 
BIDI”, which is not the position in the present case. Therefore, the said 
judgment does not further the case of the petitioner. 
12. 
Counsel for the petitioner also submitted that the matter be remanded 
back to the Registry for reconsideration of the trademark application of the 
respondent no.1 from the stage of issuance of examination report. I am not 
inclined to remand back the matter as this would amount to cancellation of 
the registration already granted in favour of the respondent no.1 as far back 
as in 2012. Therefore, I proceed to consider the matter on merits, i.e., 
whether the registration in favour of the respondent no.1 was granted 
erroneously. 
13. 
At the time when the respondent no.1 filed its application for 
registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” in 2010, there was one mark of the 
predecessor of the petitioner, “CLARI-FI”, that was registered in Class 03. 
All other marks of the petitioner with the term “Clari” have been registered 
subsequent to the registration of the respondent no.1. The petitioner acquired 
rights in the mark “CLARI-FI” in 2013, pursuant to the Asset Transfer 
Agreement dated 19th September, 2013. It is submitted on behalf of the 
petitioner that since the mark of the respondent no.1, “CLARIWASH” was 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 9 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 9 of 10 
 
similar to the earlier registered trademark “CLARI-FI”, in respect of similar 
goods, the respondent no.1 should not have been granted registration in 
terms of Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. In my considered view, 
there is no similarity in the marks “CLARI-FI” and “CLARIWASH” so as 
to cause a likelihood of confusion in the public or likelihood of association 
of “CLARIWASH” with “CLARI-FI”. It is a settled position of law that 
while comparing the marks, the marks have to be seen as a whole and 
cannot be broken into their individual components. Reference in this regard 
may be made to the judgment of the Supreme Court in Corn Products 
Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd., AIR 1960 SC 142. 
Therefore, “CLARIWASH” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “WASH” and 
similarly, “CLARI-FI” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “FI”. Taken as a 
whole, there is no similarity in the competing marks so as to cause 
confusion.  Therefore, on the basis of registration of the mark “CLARI-FI”, 
the petitioner cannot seek cancellation of the trademark “CLARIWASH” 
registered in favour of the respondent no.1 in Class 03.  
14. 
Under the Asset Transfer Agreement dated 19th September, 2013, the 
petitioner took over approximately 170 marks, both registered and pending 
registration, from Cheryl‟s Consmeceuticals. Only 12 out of the 170 marks 
use “Clari” as a part of the mark. Therefore, the petitioner cannot say that 
there was a family of marks with the term “Clari” as part of the marks that 
were registered in favour of the petitioner. 
15. 
Counsel for the petitioner has contended that even though the user 
shown in the application filed by the respondent no.1 is 16th November, 
2009, the first invoice placed on record is of 12th May, 2010. In my view, 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 10 ---
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 10 of 10 
 
this would not make any difference as registration can be granted on a 
„proposed to be used‟ basis. Even if the first user of the respondent no.1 is 
taken to be 12th May, 2010, the user of the petitioner or its predecessor of 
the trademark “CLARIWASH” is after the said date. Nothing has been 
placed on record on behalf of the petitioner to show that the mark 
“CLARIWASH” was adopted in 2010 either by the petitioner or its 
predecessor. It was only on 22nd August, 2013 that a license was issued by 
the FDA, Maharashtra in favour of the predecessor of the petitioner, 
Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals. Even the first invoice placed on record by the 
petitioner that corresponds to the use of “CLARIWASH” is dated 5th 
December, 2013 and the sales figures in the petition have been given only 
from the year 2014. It is also relevant to note that the petitioner has not filed 
any application for registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” till date.   
16. 
In light of the discussion above, no grounds for rectification are made 
out.   
17. 
The petition is dismissed with no order as to costs. 
 
 
                       AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 23, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary**

The case involves a trademark dispute between L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd (Petitioner) and Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care and anr (Respondents). The Petitioner has filed a cancellation petition (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022) seeking removal of the Respondent No.1's registered trademark "CLARIWASH" (reg. no.1950938 in Class 03).

**Key Facts and Proceedings**

* Judgment reserved on: February 27, 2023
* Judgment delivered on: March 23, 2023
* Petitioner is the owner of various trademarks with the word "Clari", engaged in manufacturing and sale of hair care, skin care, toiletries, and beauty products.
* Respondent No.1 applied for registration of "CLARIWASH" on April 16, 2010, showing user from November 16, 2009, but evidence suggests user started after May 10, 2010.
* Petitioner claims prior user status based on predecessor's use since 2009.

**Arguments and Decision**

No detailed arguments are mentioned in the provided section. The Judge's decision is not clearly stated, but it appears that the case was likely decided based on prior user rights.

**Parties and Dates**

* Petitioner: L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd.
* Respondents: Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care and anr
* Judgment reserved and delivered dates: February 27, 2023 (reserved) and March 23, 2023 (delivered)
* Date of application for trademark registration: April 16, 2010

**PDF Source**

Source: L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
**Case Summary from Page 2 of LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf**

The petitioner, L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd., is the proprietor of various trademarks with the word "Clari". The case revolves around a dispute over the trademark registration of "CLARIWASH" and other "Clari" formative marks.

**Key Facts:**

* The petitioner adopted the "CLARIWASH" mark in 2010.
* A company, Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals, adopted the first "Clari" formative marks in 2009.
* The petitioner acquired Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals in 2013 and transferred the reputation and goodwill related to the "Clari" marks.
* Respondent no.1 applied for registration of "CLARIWASH" on April 16, 2010, showing user from November 16, 2009.

**Notices:**

* Registration granted to the petitioner in respect of trademark "CLARI-FI" on February 3, 2010.
* First invoice filed by Respondent no.1 is dated May 10, 2010, after registration of petitioner's marks.

**PDF Source:** LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf (High Court of Delhi at New Delhi)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 2 of 10 
 
CASE SET UP BY THE PETITIONER 
2. 
The case set up in the petition is as under: 
2.1. The petitioner is the registered proprietor of various trademarks with 
the word “Clari”, details of which are given in paragraph 4 of the 
petition. The petitioner is engaged in the business of manufacture and 
sale of a wide range of hair care, skin care, toiletries and beauty 
products.  
2.2. The “CLARIWASH” mark was adopted in 2010 by the petitioner and 
has been used along with the other “Clari” formative marks. 
2.3. The first of the “Clari” formative marks were adopted by a company 
by the name of Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals Pvt. Ltd. [hereinafter 
“Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals”] in 2009. The petitioner acquired Cheryl‟s 
Cosmeceuticals in 2013 by way of a Deed of Assignment and Asset 
Transfer Agreement.  
2.4. By virtue of the said Deed of Assignment and Transfer Agreement, 
the reputation and goodwill related to various “Clari” formative marks 
stood transferred to the petitioner. 
2.5. The petitioner is the prior user of the “Clari” formative marks from 
the year 2009 on account of the user of his predecessor. 
2.6. The respondent no.1 applied for registration of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH” in Class 03 on 16th April, 2010 showing user from 
16th November, 2009. However, the first invoice filed on behalf of the 
respondent no.1 is dated 10th May, 2010, which is after the 
registration of the “Clari” formative marks. On the other hand, the 
registration granted in favour of the petitioner in respect of trademark 
“CLARI-FI” is of 3rd February, 2010 with user from 1st April, 2009. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
Legal Document Summary: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar (2023:DHC:2089)

**Background**

Section 12 of the Trademarks Act is at issue in this case filed by L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd against Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care, over a trademark dispute.

**Facts**

* L'Oreal had challenged the registration of trademark "CLARIWASH" by Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading, citing prior use and identical/similar mark.
* The Examiner's Report noted the mark as "CHARIWASH", leading to a Certificate of Registration in that name. Later corrected to "CLARIWASH".
* L'Oreal claims adoption of "CLARIWASH" in 2010 but failed to provide supporting documents for this.
* Respondent had commenced a suit against L'Oreal in District Courts, Tis Hazari.

**Arguments**

Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading's arguments:

* Cannot claim concurrent user under Section 12 as did not use mark at time of application filing.
* Trademark Registry error corrected by issuing a fresh Certificate for "CLARIWASH", relying on Epsilon Publishing House Private Limited vs Union of India (2009 SCC OnLine Del).
* L'Oreal's adoption and usage of the mark came later, in 2013.

**Decisions**

Court to deliberate on this matter given trademark registration errors and concurrent user under Section 12.

PDF Source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf
tree_structure.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the PDF:

The petitioner (Loreal India PVT. LTD) submits that the respondent (Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading) cannot claim benefit of "concurrent user" under Section 12 of Trademarks Act as they had no use of the trademark at the time of application.

* Respondent's trademark application was filed on April 16, 2010.
* Earliest invoice from respondent is dated May 10, 2010, more than a month after application filing.
* Examination Report issued by Registrar notes respondent's mark as "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH", resulting in Certificate of Registration for "CHARIWASH".
* Registry later modified certificate to "CLARIWASH".

The petitioner argues that the Registry made an error in changing the registration certificate and should have proceeded with a fresh examination.

PDF source: LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, 2023:DHC:2089 (High Court of Delhi)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 3 of 10 
 
2.7. It is further submitted that the respondent no.1 cannot claim the 
benefit of concurrent user under Section 12 of the Trademarks Act as 
there was no use by the respondent no.1 at the time of the trademark 
application. The trademark application was filed on 16th April, 2010 
and the earliest invoice filed on behalf of the respondents is of 10th 
May, 2010. 
2.8. The Examination Report dated 3rd January, 2012 issued by the 
Registrar of Trade Marks wrongly notes the mark of the respondent 
no.1 as “CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Based on the 
aforesaid Examination Report, the Certificate of Registration of Trade 
Mark was issued in favour of the respondent no.1 for the word mark 
“CHARIWASH”. However, subsequently, the Certificate was 
modified by the Registry to “CLARIWASH”. 
2.9. The procedure adopted by the Registry in changing the Registration 
Certificate of word mark from “CHARIWASH” to “CLARIWASH” 
was an erroneous. Having discovered the error, the Registry should 
have 
proceeded 
for 
a 
fresh 
examination 
for 
the 
mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance in this regard is placed on the orders of the 
Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) in Vans Inc. USA v. 
Fateh Chand Bhansali and Anr., 2020 SCC OnLine IPAB 44 and 
Prajapati Constructions Ltd. v.  Manoj Ramanand Prajapati and 
Anr., 2018 SCC OnLine IPAB 313. 
CASE SET UP BY THE RESPONDENT 
3. 
The case set up by the respondent no.1 is as under:

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 4 from PDF: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf:

**Trademark Dispute**

The respondent No.1 has filed a suit against L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd. (petitioner) for infringement of its registered trademark "CLARIWASH". The dispute is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari.

Key facts and arguments:

* Trademark Registry erroneously issued a certificate for the mark "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH".
* Respondent No.1 rectified the error and obtained a fresh registration certificate for "CLARIWASH" in 2012 (Epsilon Publishing House Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India and Ors., 2009 SCC OnLine Del 3922).
* Petitioner claims adoption of the mark in 2010, but no evidence has been filed to support this.
* Petitioner does not have a registered trademark for "CLARIWASH".
* Petitioner's use of the mark started only in 2013.

**Source:** PDF: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf (2023:DHC:2089)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 4 of 10 
 
3.1. The respondent no.1 has filed a suit for infringement of the registered 
trademark “CLARIWASH” of the respondent no.1 against the 
petitioner, which is pending before the District Courts, Tis Hazari. 
3.2. Even though the Examination Report was in respect of the mark 
“CHARIWASH”, the Trademark Journal correctly published the 
mark “CLARIWASH” and not “CHARIWASH”. In May, 2012, the 
Trademark Registry erroneously issued Trademark Registration 
Certificate for the word mark “CHARIWASH”. The respondent no.1 
immediately filed an application to rectify the said clerical error and 
accordingly, the Trademark Registry rectified the error and issued a 
fresh Trademark Registration Certificate for the correct word mark 
“CLARIWASH”. Reliance is placed on the judgment of a Coordinate 
Bench in Epsilon Publishing House Pvt. Ltd. v. Union of India and 
Ors., 2009 SCC OnLine Del 3922.  
3.3. Though the petitioner claims adoption of the mark “CLARIWASH” 
in the year 2010, nothing has been filed in support of the same. 
Further, the petitioner has not filed any application for registration of 
the mark “CLARIWASH” till date. 
3.4. Use of the mark “CLARIWASH” by the petitioner or its predecessor 
was only in the year 2013. Attention of the Court in this regard is 
drawn to the invoices filed on behalf petitioner. 
3.5. The petitioner uses several other marks other than the “Clari” 
formative marks. Therefore, it cannot be said that “Clari” belongs to a 
family of marks. 
3.6. The petitioner cannot claim any monopoly on a part of the trademark 
“Clari”. The fact that the petitioner has various marks registered with 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
The content of page 5 from PDF: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf (2023:DHC:2089 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022) is as follows:

The court has heard counsels for both parties and observed the following facts:

* The Trademarks Registry issued an Examination Report and a Registration Certificate in favor of respondent no.1, but mistakenly showed "CHARIWASH" instead of "CLARIWASH".
* An application was later filed by respondent no.2 to rectify the error on June 14, 2012, which was allowed by the Registry.
* A correct Trademark Registration Certificate was issued for "CLARIWASH", and the mark had been correctly published in the Trademark Journal No.1519 on January 16, 2012.

This information indicates that:

* Date: January 16, 2012 (Publication of mark "CLARIWASH")
* Date: June 14, 2012 (Application for rectification)
* Party: Respondent no.1
* Event: Erroneous issuance of Examination Report and Registration Certificate
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 5 of 10 
 
the prefix “Clari” does not mean that the registration granted in favour 
of the respondent no.1 for the mark “CLARIWASH” is defective. 
There are a number of trademarks registered where the word “Clari” 
has been used as a prefix or suffix.  
3.7. The petitioner was aware of the respondent‟s use of the trademark 
“CLARIWASH”, yet never applied for its trademark registration. 
4. 
Despite opportunity being granted, the respondent no.2 has not filed 
any reply/counter statement or written submissions in the present petition. 
ANALYSIS AND FINDINGS 
5. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
6. 
In the present case, it appears from the record that the Trademarks 
Registry erroneously issued the Examination Report for the mark 
“CHARIWASH” instead of “CLARIWASH”. Yet again, the Registry issued 
a Trademark Registration Certificate in favour of the respondent, wherein 
the mark of the respondent was wrongly shown as “CHARIWASH”. 
Immediately thereafter, an application was filed on behalf of the respondents 
on 14th June, 2012, requesting for rectification of the clerical error and the 
same was allowed by the Registry and a correct Trademark Registration 
Certificate was issued in favour of the respondent for the mark 
“CLARIWASH”. However, it is pertinent to note that the mark of the 
respondent no.1 was published correctly as “CLARIWASH” in the 
Trademark Journal No.1519 on 16th January, 2012.  Therefore, it was open 
for the petitioner or its predecessor to oppose the said application, which 
they failed to do. 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Legal Proceedings:**

The High Court of Delhi (2023:DHC:2089) heard a matter between L'Oréal India PVT. LTD. and Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care, regarding trademark registration.

**Facts:**

* The Trademark Registry issued a faulty examination report.
* Respondent no.1 was granted trademark registration despite the error.
* Petitioner (L'Oréal) seeks removal of trademark registration on account of mistake by the Registry.

**Arguments:**

* Counsel for respondent no.1 (Rajesh Kumar Taneja) argued that he cannot be faulted for a mistake committed by the Registry.
* Relying on Epsilon Publishing, the Court was asked to consider whether the Registrar's error can lead to removal of trademark registration.
* Petitioner relied on interim orders from IPAB in Prajapati Constructions and Vans Inc. USA, stating that the Trademark Registry must follow statutory procedure.

**Decisions:**

* The Court held that respondent no.1 cannot be deprived of valuable rights due to error by the Registry (Sections 7-9).
* The dictum in Epsilon Publishing was applied to the present case.
* IPAB interim orders were deemed not binding at the final hearing stage, highlighting procedural lapses by the Trademark Registry.

**Parties:**

* L'Oréal India PVT. LTD. (Petitioner)
* Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care (Respondent no.1)

**Dates:**

* Judgment Reserved: 27th February, 2023
* Judgment Delivered: 23rd March, 2023

**Source:** LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf, Page 6-10 of 10.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF:

The court concludes that an error by the registry in issuing a faulty examination report cannot be used as grounds for removing the registration granted to respondent no.1. The respondent cannot be faulted for misleading or misrepresenting information, and deprivation of registration due to a mistake by the registry would be unjust.

A similar case, Epsilon Publishing (not quoted further), held that a respondent cannot be penalized when the Trade Marks Registry fails to adhere to statutory timelines. In this case, the Registrar admitted not examining a renewal application, but the private respondent was allowed to pursue its rights despite the fault of the Registrar. 

Note: The PDF source is "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar" (2023:DHC:2089), Case No. C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022.
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 6 of 10 
 
7. 
If the Registrar has committed an error and issued a faulty 
examination report, the respondent no.1 cannot be faulted for the same.  It is 
not that the respondent no.1 had misrepresented or misled the trademark 
Registry into issuing a faulty examination report.  The registration of a 
trademark entails valuable rights and the respondent no.1 cannot be deprived 
of the same on account of mistake committed by the Registry. Therefore, 
this by itself cannot be the ground for removal of the registration granted in 
favour of the respondent no.1. 
8. 
In Epsilon Publishing (supra), a Coordinate Bench of this Court was 
seized of a petition challenging the order of the Registrar renewing the 
trademark granted in favour of the respondent therein.  The ground taken by 
the petitioner was that since the respondent had not filed an application for 
renewal of the registration before its expiration and not paid the surcharge, 
the Registrar was required to remove the trademark from the Register.  
While noting that the Trade Marks Registry has not adhered to the statutory 
timelines, it was held that the respondent cannot be penalized for the same 
and would be entitled to pursue its renewal application.  In the said case, the 
Registrar had admitted that the renewal application filed on behalf of the 
private respondent was not examined and therefore, could not be processed 
further.  It was observed that the private respondent could not be deprived of 
its rights on account of the fault of the Registrar. The relevant observations 
of the court as set out in paragraph 26 are reproduced below: 
“26. 
There may be merit in the contention that the Registrar 
has to follow the procedure as prescribed; however, the essential 
question is not whether the Registrar has any discretion in the 
matter, but, what are the consequences of the Registrar not 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the provided PDF:

**Case:** LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar (2023:DHC:2089)

**Page 7 Summary:**

The court finds that the Trademark Registry has not adhered to the timelines as required under the Trade Marks Act, 1999. Respondent No.3 had filed its application for renewal of its trademark well within the prescribed period and was entitled to know the fate of its application. The Registry did not advertise the removal of the trademark as required, which would have provided an opportunity for the petitioner to seek restoration.

**Applicable Dicta:** The court cites a previous judgment, applicable to the present case, which states that the respondent cannot be deprived of its valuable rights of registration on account of the error of the Registry.

**IPAB Rulings:** The counsel for the petitioner relies on interim orders passed by the IPAB in Prajapati Constructions (supra) and Vans Inc. USA (supra), but the court notes that these rulings are not relevant at this stage of final hearing.

**Source:** 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 7 of 10 
 
following the established procedure? Plainly, in the facts of the 
present case, it is apparent that the Trademark Registry has not 
adhered to the timelines as required. Surely, respondent no.3 
cannot be penalised for the same and would be entitled to purse its 
application for renewal of its trademark. The same was filed well 
within the period of six months and even though the same was not 
accompanied by a fee of surcharge, nonetheless, respondent no.3 
had the right to know the fate of its application. Since no 
deficiency was pointed out at the material time, respondent no.3 
cannot be deprived of its valuable rights to cure the defects within 
the prescribed period. The Registrar also did not advertise the 
removal of the trademark as required under section 25(4) of the 
Act read with Rule 66 of the 2002 Rules. Such advertisement 
would have provided another opportunity for the petitioner to seek 
restoration of the trademark.” 
9. 
The dicta of the aforesaid judgment is squarely applicable to the 
present case. The respondent no.1 cannot be deprived of his valuable rights 
of registration on account of the error of the Registry. 
10. 
Counsel for the petitioner has relied upon the orders passed by the 
IPAB in Prajapati Constructions (supra) and Vans Inc. USA (supra) in 
support of his submission that the Registrar of Trade Marks has to follow 
the statutory procedure prescribed under the Trade Marks Act, 1999 in 
respect of examination of a trade mark application. At the outset, it may be 
noted that both are interim orders passed by the IPAB and therefore, no 
reliance can be placed on the same in the present case, which is at the stage 
of final hearing. After noticing the various procedural lapses committed by 
the Trademark Registry, the IPAB only ordered that the respondent therein 
shall not rely upon the impugned registration in any proceedings during the 
pendency of the rectification proceedings.  There was no order for removal 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 8
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from the PDF document:

**LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar (2023:DHC:2089)**

Page 8 states that the respondent's trademark registration was granted due to lapses committed by the Registry. The petitioner argues that this was an error.

The court relies on a previous judgment, **Jahangir Biri Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Mohd. Dildar Hossain (Proporietor) & Anr., 2018 (76) PTC 479 [IPAB]**, where the marks of the petitioner and respondent were identical, but notes that this is not applicable in the present case.

The petitioner's counsel submits that the matter be remanded back to the Registry for reconsideration. However, the court declines, considering it would amount to cancellation of the respondent's registration granted in 2012.

**Key points:**

* Respondent's trademark registration was granted due to Registry lapses.
* Court relies on previous judgment with similar marks but notes difference in present case.
* Petitioner's counsel requests remand back to Registry for reconsideration, which is declined.
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 8 of 10 
 
of the registration granted in favour of the respondent on account of lapses 
committed by the Registry.  
11. 
Reliance has also been placed on the order passed by the IPAB in 
Jahangir Biri Factory Pvt. Ltd. v. Mohd. Dildar Hossain (Proporietor) & 
Anr., 2018 (76) PTC 479 [IPAB]. In the aforesaid order, the marks of the 
petitioner and the respondent were identical, namely, “HOWRAH BIDI”. 
The respondent therein had merely added a number to the mark “HOWRAH 
BIDI”, which is not the position in the present case. Therefore, the said 
judgment does not further the case of the petitioner. 
12. 
Counsel for the petitioner also submitted that the matter be remanded 
back to the Registry for reconsideration of the trademark application of the 
respondent no.1 from the stage of issuance of examination report. I am not 
inclined to remand back the matter as this would amount to cancellation of 
the registration already granted in favour of the respondent no.1 as far back 
as in 2012. Therefore, I proceed to consider the matter on merits, i.e., 
whether the registration in favour of the respondent no.1 was granted 
erroneously. 
13. 
At the time when the respondent no.1 filed its application for 
registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” in 2010, there was one mark of the 
predecessor of the petitioner, “CLARI-FI”, that was registered in Class 03. 
All other marks of the petitioner with the term “Clari” have been registered 
subsequent to the registration of the respondent no.1. The petitioner acquired 
rights in the mark “CLARI-FI” in 2013, pursuant to the Asset Transfer 
Agreement dated 19th September, 2013. It is submitted on behalf of the 
petitioner that since the mark of the respondent no.1, “CLARIWASH” was 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL

nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary:** LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar (2023:DHC:2089)

The Delhi High Court dismissed a petition filed by L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd. seeking cancellation of the trademark "CLARIWASH" registered in favor of Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading as Innovative Derma Care (Respondent No. 1) on grounds that it was deceptively similar to L'Oréal's previously registered trademark "CLARI-FI".

**Facts and Arguments:**

* L'Oréal India Pvt. Ltd. took over approximately 170 marks from Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals in 2013, but only 12 of them used the term "Clari" as part of the mark.
* The Respondent No. 1 obtained registration for "CLARIWASH" on November 16, 2009 (user shown), with first invoice dated May 12, 2010 (placed on record).
* L'Oréal contended that the use and registration of "CLARIWASH" would cause a likelihood of confusion with "CLARI-FI".
* The Court held that while comparing marks, they must be seen as a whole and not broken down into individual components.

**Decision:**

* The Court found no similarity between the marks "CLARI-FI" and "CLARIWASH" to cause confusion or association.
* Registration of "CLARI-FI" does not prevent other users from registering similar marks, especially when seen as a whole.
* No grounds for rectification were made out.

**Dates:**

* Judgment Reserved on: 27th February, 2023
* Judgment Delivered on: 23rd March, 2023

**Source:** 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar (PDF file from 2023:DHC:2089)
tree_structure.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 9
nodes.summary:
Based on page 9 of the PDF document "LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar" (`2023:DHC:2089`), here is a summary of the key points:

**Arguments against cancellation**

* The court finds no similarity between the marks "CLARI-FI" and "CLARIWASH", which means there is no likelihood of confusion among consumers.
* The court relies on the Supreme Court judgment in Corn Products Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd., AIR 1960 SC 142, which states that comparable marks should be viewed as a whole.

**Analysis of mark usage**

* Petitioner took over approximately 170 marks from Cheryl's Cosmeceuticals under an Asset Transfer Agreement dated 19th September, 2013.
* Only 12 out of the 170 marks use "Clari" as part of the mark.

**Dates and facts**

* First invoice submitted by respondent no.1 was on May 12, 2010 (more than a year after claimed user date of November 16, 2009).

Source: PDF document LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar (`2023:DHC:2089`) Page 9 of 10
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 9 of 10 
 
similar to the earlier registered trademark “CLARI-FI”, in respect of similar 
goods, the respondent no.1 should not have been granted registration in 
terms of Section 11 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999. In my considered view, 
there is no similarity in the marks “CLARI-FI” and “CLARIWASH” so as 
to cause a likelihood of confusion in the public or likelihood of association 
of “CLARIWASH” with “CLARI-FI”. It is a settled position of law that 
while comparing the marks, the marks have to be seen as a whole and 
cannot be broken into their individual components. Reference in this regard 
may be made to the judgment of the Supreme Court in Corn Products 
Refining Co. v. Shangrila Food Products Ltd., AIR 1960 SC 142. 
Therefore, “CLARIWASH” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “WASH” and 
similarly, “CLARI-FI” cannot be read as “CLARI” plus “FI”. Taken as a 
whole, there is no similarity in the competing marks so as to cause 
confusion.  Therefore, on the basis of registration of the mark “CLARI-FI”, 
the petitioner cannot seek cancellation of the trademark “CLARIWASH” 
registered in favour of the respondent no.1 in Class 03.  
14. 
Under the Asset Transfer Agreement dated 19th September, 2013, the 
petitioner took over approximately 170 marks, both registered and pending 
registration, from Cheryl‟s Consmeceuticals. Only 12 out of the 170 marks 
use “Clari” as a part of the mark. Therefore, the petitioner cannot say that 
there was a family of marks with the term “Clari” as part of the marks that 
were registered in favour of the petitioner. 
15. 
Counsel for the petitioner has contended that even though the user 
shown in the application filed by the respondent no.1 is 16th November, 
2009, the first invoice placed on record is of 12th May, 2010. In my view, 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
nodes.pdf_source: 3. LOREAL INDIA PVT. LTD vs Kumar.pdf

nodes.title: Page 10
nodes.summary:
**PDF Source:** L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd vs Kumar (2023:DHC:2089)

**Summary of Page 10:**

The judgment reserves on February 27, 2023, and is delivered on March 23, 2023.

**Key Findings:**

1. **Trademark Registration**: The court rules that registration can be granted on a "proposed to be used" basis.
2. **Priority Date**: Even if the respondent's first user date is taken as May 12, 2010, the petitioner's (L'Oreal) use of the trademark "CLARIWASH" is after this date.
3. **Lack of Evidence**: No evidence was presented to show that L'Oreal or its predecessor adopted the mark "CLARIWASH" in 2010.

**Decision:**

* The petition for rectification of the trademark registration is dismissed with no order as to costs.

**Parties:**

1. L'Oreal India Pvt. Ltd. (Petitioner)
2. Rajesh Kumar Taneja Trading Co. (Respondent)
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:2089 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 497/2022 
                                          
 
      Page 10 of 10 
 
this would not make any difference as registration can be granted on a 
„proposed to be used‟ basis. Even if the first user of the respondent no.1 is 
taken to be 12th May, 2010, the user of the petitioner or its predecessor of 
the trademark “CLARIWASH” is after the said date. Nothing has been 
placed on record on behalf of the petitioner to show that the mark 
“CLARIWASH” was adopted in 2010 either by the petitioner or its 
predecessor. It was only on 22nd August, 2013 that a license was issued by 
the FDA, Maharashtra in favour of the predecessor of the petitioner, 
Cheryl‟s Cosmeceuticals. Even the first invoice placed on record by the 
petitioner that corresponds to the use of “CLARIWASH” is dated 5th 
December, 2013 and the sales figures in the petition have been given only 
from the year 2014. It is also relevant to note that the petitioner has not filed 
any application for registration of the mark “CLARIWASH” till date.   
16. 
In light of the discussion above, no grounds for rectification are made 
out.   
17. 
The petition is dismissed with no order as to costs. 
 
 
                       AMIT BANSAL, J. 
MARCH 23, 2023 
at 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:23.03.2023 17:39:04
Signature Not Verified
